body: Virus scanning. The system can scan all uploaded documents for viruses for additional security. If the system detects a virus, the document upload is prevented. By default, virus scanning is disabled. Contact FA if you want to enable virus scanning.

title: Related links
body: Preference - Administration in FA Back reference

title: Document signing
body: FA document signing allows you to:

title: Document signing
body: Send documents from the FA document bank to be signed by end clients with their BankID (Signicat signing service).

title: Document signing
body: Monitor the signing status of documents.

title: Document signing
body: Cancel document signing requests.

title: Document signing
body: FA provides Signicat services through FA agreements. We charge customers separately for these services.

title: Document signing
body: The following sections describe how you can ask the end client for authentication to view the document and administer the document signing functionality.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Ask for authentication to view a document

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: When you send a document for signing, the system by default requires authentication (for example, BankID) from the signee before they can view the document. You can adjust this setting by doing the following:

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Signicat sign.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: See the Don't require authentication before viewing the document field in the Authentication section.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: To require authentication from the signee, make sure the checkbox is unticked (default).

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: To disable the mandatory authentication, tick the checkbox.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Click Done.

title: Ask for authentication to view a document
body: Authentication settings are now saved and the system asks the signee to authenticate depending on your selection.

title: Administer document signing functionality
body: Administer document signing functionality

title: Administer document signing functionality
body: Before you can use the document signing functionality, FA needs to order the signing method from Signicat and finalise the configuration of the signing process for you.

title: Related links
body: Manage documents in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Set up document signing notifications in FA Admin guide

title: Send documents for signing
body: FA allows you to send documents for signing to one or more end clients. The signees receive a link to the document via email or SMS. When they have signed the document, you can download it in FA Back.

title: Send documents for signing
body: To send a document for signing, do the following:

title: Send documents for signing
body: Make sure the following signee details are defined in the Contact window:

title: Send documents for signing
body: Social security number or national identification number in Basic info tab, External ID field.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Email and Phone fields in Address info tab. The document link is sent to the contact's first email address and to their phone number if defined. The email address and phone number are required if you select to send signing notifications always. If you set signing notifications to "If valid email address/phone number is found", the corresponding field is required. For details on signing notification settings, see ???.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Upload documents in the Contact, Portfolio, Transaction or Trade order window, Documents tab. Add the "Document signing-Waiting" tag.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Go to the Contacts view and select the signee's contact. Click Document signing → Send documents for signing at the bottom of the view.

title: Send documents for signing
body: Check the Validation column of documents you want to send. If a document has errors, you need to correct them before it can be sent. Typically, errors relate to missing signee details (see step 1).

title: Send documents for signing
body: Click Send.

title: Send documents for signing
body: The system produces a notification that shows the number of documents sent and the number of errors. Sent documents are tagged with "Document signing-Pending". Documents with errors are tagged with "Document signing-Error".

title: Send documents for signing
body: The signee receives an email with a link to view and sign the sent documents. When they sign the document, the system saves it in the Documents tab of the window where you uploaded it (Contact, Portfolio, Transaction, or Trade order window). You can then download the signed document.

title: Add multiple signees
body: Add multiple signees

title: Add multiple signees
body: If you need multiple end clients to sign the document, you can add signees who are not linked to the portfolio, transaction, or trade order:

title: Add multiple signees
body: Open the Contact window, Document signing tab of the main signee.

title: Add multiple signees
body: Create a list of signees from available contacts using the arrow buttons. The selected signees need to have the same contact details defined as the main signee (see step 1).

title: Add multiple signees
body: Click Save & close.

title: Add multiple signees
body: When you send a document for signing, all signees on the list now receive a link to the document.

title: Schedule document sending
body: You can schedule the system to send documents for signing on a regular basis. When you schedule document sending, the system tries to send all documents tagged with "Document signing-Waiting". If a document has errors, the parent objects of the document (portfolio or contact) are tagged with "Document signing-Error". The document itself is not tagged, so the system sends it after you correct the validation errors. For more information on scheduling, see Scheduling in FA Admin guide.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: FA allows you to track the signing status of documents so that you know, for example, which documents are waiting for their signees and which documents you need to make corrections for. You can use the following methods to open the Document status list window:

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Open Contacts, Portfolios, Transactions, or Trade orders view and select the ones to view documents for → Document signing → Monitor document signing status.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Go to Tools → Monitor → Document signing status.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: The window shows the following information for each document:

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Status

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Current signing status of the document. For the list of statuses and their meanings, see Document signing statuses.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Signers

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Number of signees that have signed the document out of the total number of signees.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Contact

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Contact, portfolio, transaction, or trade order under which the document is stored.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Document

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Name of the document.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Date sent

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Date when the document was sent for signing.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Last modified

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Last date and time the document information was modified.

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Validation

title: Monitor document signing status
body: Errors in the document information, for example, missing signee details. The column is empty if no errors are found. The document can only be sent for signing when it has no errors.

title: Document signing statuses
body: The following document signing statuses and corresponding tags are available:

title: Document signing statuses
body: Not sent. The document is waiting to be sent for signing and has the tag "Document signing-Waiting".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Pending. The document is sent and waiting to be signed and has the tag "Document signing-Pending".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Error. The object that contains the document or contact information has errors. The document has the tag "Document signing-Error". Fix the errors and tag the document with "Document signing-Waiting".

title: Document signing statuses
body: Done. The document is signed and has the tag "Document signing-Done". Both the original and signed document are saved in the FA system.

title: Document signing statuses
body: Canceled. The document signing was canceled by the initiator. The document has the tag "Document signing-Canceled".

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can monitor the signing status of documents under a specific contact:

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Open the Contacts view and select the contact to monitor.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Click Document signing → Monitor document signing status to open the signing status window.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Check the Validation column for errors. For documents with errors, you can click on the contact name to open the Overview and edit the missing or incorrect information.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can use the same method for portfolios, transactions, and trade orders as well.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: You can also monitor the signing status of documents stored under contacts, portfolios, transactions, and trade orders in one window:

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Go to Tools → Monitor → Document signing status. The window that opens shows a list of all documents with a tag related to the document signing process.

title: Examples of monitoring document signing status
body: Click the rows highlighted with "Error" to open the Overview. Edit the missing or incorrect information.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: To cancel a signing request, do the following:

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Open the Tasks view.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Filter the task list to find the request to cancel. Signing request task titles follow the pattern: "<datetime> Awaiting signature: <document path>".

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Use the My tasks list to cancel your own signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Use the All tasks list to cancel someone else's signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: Open the signing request task and click Cancel signing request.

title: Cancel signing requests
body: The signing request is canceled both on the Signicat side and on the FA side. If you need to send the document for signing again, tag the document with "Document signing-Waiting" and follow the instructions in Send documents for signing.

title: Send documents via email
body: FA allows you to send documents stored under a contact, portfolio, transaction, or trade order to end clients via email.

title: Send documents via email
body: For sending reports, the process is different (see Send reports via email).

title: Send documents via email
body: To send documents via email, do the following:

title: Send documents via email
body: Add the tag "Document sending-Waiting" to the documents you want to send.

title: Send documents via email
body: Go to Tools → Send documents via emails and use the checkboxes on the left side of the window to select which documents to send.

title: Send documents via email
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Send documents via email
body: Source of reporting addresses

title: Send documents via email
body: Source of the recipient email addresses. Select "Contact" to use the email address defined in the Contact window, Address info tab. Select "Portfolio" to use the email address defined in the Portfolio window, Reporting tab. You can see the email addresses fetched the source in the Recipient email address(es) column.

title: Send documents via email
body: Email template

title: Send documents via email
body: Email message template defined in Preference → Reporting → Email. For more information about email templates, see Send and receive emails and SMS messages.

title: Send documents via email
body: Click Send.

title: Send documents via email
body: The documents are sent to the end client.

title: Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities
body: Configurable key figures allow you to define what key figure values you want to store on your contacts, portfolios and securities. Key figures allow you to store a time series of values of your choice. For example, you can store fee percentages that change over time to your portfolios, or your key figure on your instruments, extending the possibilities of storing data into FA.

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: Contacts and portfolios are imported in FA in semicolon-separated CSV files, with the file columns described below. You can import multiple contacts or portfolios in one file, but you can't import contacts and portfolios in the same file.

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: You can set the following properties of the CSV file in Preference → Importing → File format (see Preference - Importing for details):

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: File delimiter. By default, FA is configured to accept semicolon-separated values. You can change it to another character.

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: Encoding (UTF-8 or Windows-1252). To import Scandinavian letters, the files should be Windows-1252 encoded to guarantee the correct handling of Scandinavian letters.

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: Download the CSV file templates:

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: FAFormat_portfolios.csv

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: FAFormat_contacts.csv

title: File formats for importing contacts and portfolios
body: The file columns are described below.

title: Updating contacts and portfolios
body: You can update existing contacts and portfolios by importing a new file with corrected data.

title: Updating contacts and portfolios
body: The system identifies the contact to update by the Contact ID, and the portfolio to update by the Portfolio ID, so these fields must be filled in.

title: Updating contacts and portfolios
body: Note that you must specify if you want to keep the old values in each field:

title: Updating contacts and portfolios
body: To replace the field value, specify the new value in the import file.

title: Updating contacts and portfolios
body: To keep the existing field value saved in the system, add three stars *** in the field. Note that if you import an empty field without ***, the field value previously saved in the system is removed. For multi-value fields, you can import new values while keeping the old ones using three stars (***), for example, ***<new value1>,<new value2>.

title: Updating contacts and portfolios
body: Some fields have specific syntax for updates, see the field descriptions in the tables.

title: Removing contact and portfolio values with three minuses (---)
body: You can remove individual values from multi-value fields by marking them with three minuses (---) in the CSV file. Currently, this syntax can be used for removing tag and profile values (tags and profileAttributes fields). To remove a value, specify the Contact ID or Portfolio ID in the first column and add the values you want to remove prefixed with three minuses (---). If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to put an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.

title: Removing contact and portfolio values with three minuses (---)
body: To remove multiple values, divide them with a comma for tags, and with a hash (#) for profile attributes. For example: ---<tag name 1>,---<tag name 2> or ---contact.profiling.totalAssets#---contact.profiling.activity.

title: Removing contact and portfolio values with three minuses (---)
body: You can remove certain values and add other ones, for example: --<tag name 1>,<tag name 2> or ---contact.profiling.totalAssets#contact.profiling.activity.

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: Limit definitions are imported into the FA system in semicolon-separated CSV files using the columns described below. Each row in the file represents a limit group.

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: You can set the following properties of the CSV file in Preference → Importing → File format (see Preference - Importing for details):

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: File delimiter. By default, FA is configured to accept semicolon-separated values. You can change it to another character.

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: Encoding (UTF-8 or Windows-1252). To import Scandinavian letters, the files should be Windows-1252 encoded to guarantee the correct handling of Scandinavian letters.

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: Download the sample file:

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: FAFormat_limit_definitions.csv

title: File formats for importing limit definitions
body: The file columns are described below.

title: Updating limit definitions
body: You can update existing limit definitions by importing a new file with corrected data.

title: Updating limit definitions
body: The system identifies to limit group to update by the Group code and the limit to update by the Limit code, so these fields must be filled in.

title: Updating limit definitions
body: Note that you must specify if you want to keep the old values in each field:

title: Updating limit definitions
body: To replace the field value, specify the new value in the import file.

title: Updating limit definitions
body: To keep the existing field value saved in the system, add three stars *** in the field. Note that if you import an empty field without ***, the field value previously saved in the system is removed. For multi-value fields, you can import new values while keeping the old ones using three stars (***), for example, ***<new value1>,<new value2>.

title: Updating limit definitions
body: Some fields have specific syntax for updates, see the field descriptions in the tables.

title: Removing limit definition values with three minuses (---)
body: You can remove individual values from multi-value fields by marking them with three minuses (---) in the CSV file.

title: Removing limit definition values with three minuses (---)
body: To remove a value, specify the Group code and Limit code in the first columns and add the values you want to remove prefixed with three minuses (---). If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to put an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---STOCK.

title: Removing limit definition values with three minuses (---)
body: To remove multiple values, divide them with a comma. For example: ---<filter 1>,---<filter 2>. You can also remove certain values while adding others, for example: --<filter 1>,<filter 2>.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Bookkeeping preferences include settings for managing and setting up accounting. The first steps in setting up accounting are to 1) create bookkeeping accounts in the system through the Account set preferences and 2) create appropriate posting rules in the Posting rule preferences.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in bookkeeping preferences are tracked:

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in account sets and posting rules are recorded in FA audit logs available in the FA Admin Console: FA audit logs.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in posting rules are recorded in versions of each posting rule: Track data modifications through versions.

title: Account set
body: Account set

title: Account set
body: In the Account set preferences, you can define account sets to be used when defining posting rules. An account set consists of a code, account set name, and individual accounts. Define an account number and name for each account.

title: Account set
body: You can add the accounts manually one by one or click Import/export and then copy and paste the accounts on separate lines as text.

title: Account set
body: You can also fetch the account name and number dynamically from the account information of a portfolio or reported transaction's security:

title: Account set
body: Typing SEC into the account number uses the transaction's security name as the account name and the transaction's security trade code as the account number.

title: Account set
body: Typing ACC into the account number uses the transaction's portfolio's secondary account number as the account code, or if not defined, the currency trade code of the portfolio account as the account code.

title: General
body: In the General preferences, you can define the logic used to create bookkeeping postings from transactions. The following table lists the configurations available:

title: Posting rule
body: Posting rule

title: Posting rule
body: In the Posting rule preferences, you can define different rules that affect the formation of the bookkeeping report or the generation of postings (if bookkeeping is enabled). These rules describe, which transactions, linked to a security with certain characteristics, are recorded to the debit and credit sides of the chosen bookkeeping account.

title: Posting rule
body: A posting rule consists of a name, a code, and a link to a defined account set. The link to an account set defines the accounts available for defining the posting rules: only the accounts defined for the linked account set are available.

title: Posting rule
body: In addition to the basic information, a posting rule consists of multiple precise rules, which are defined against a certain bookkeeping account: the whole posting rule is a combination of several, individual rules, each representing an entry in bookkeeping. A new individual rule to the posting rule is added with the Add button at the bottom of the window.

title: Posting rule
body: When posting-based bookkeeping is enabled, you can see an extended set of selectable rules and charge types compared to the available fields in standard bookkeeping. When bookkeeping is not enabled, you can only see the standard options. In addition, you can search for posting rules by filtering a posting rule set with the content of the available columns.

title: Posting rule
body: An individual rule is defined as a combination of a certain transaction type, security's characteristics, account from the chosen account set, and decision of debit/credit:

title: Posting rule
body: Transaction type*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the transaction type of the posting rule, e.g. which types of transaction the individual rule is applied to.

title: Posting rule
body: Security

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the characteristics of the securities to apply the rule to. You can choose from:

title: Posting rule
body: Security base type, Security type, Security subtype, or individual Security. You can select only one of these properties.

title: Posting rule
body: Country, Marketplace, Class (1 through 5), or Issuer. You can select one or more of these properties.

title: Posting rule
body: If you have multiple rules, specific rules are applied over more generic ones. The security characteristics are taken into account in bottom-up order. For example, if you have separate rules for security country "Finland" and security type "Stock", the rule based on the security country is applied for your Finnish stocks (the country is below the security type in the list).

title: Posting rule
body: Account*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the bookkeeping account the entry is recorded to from the account set linked to the posting rule (the accounts are defined in the Account set preferences for the linked account set)

title: Posting rule
body: Value

title: Posting rule
body: Leave empty, or choose from positive or negative. For each individual rule, you can define that the individual rule is executed and a posting is generated only if the value of the rule will be positive or negative. You can thus define that even if other rule criteria are met, only execute the individual rule if the positive/negative value criteria are met.

title: Posting rule
body: Charge type

title: Posting rule
body: Choose the charge type(s) of the rule by choosing them from the check boxes next to the type (the types available are described in the table below). Checking a charge type also allows you to combine different values by adding or subtracting them: when checking multiple types, these values are added up, and the + and - signs above the check boxes determine whether the checked value is taken into the calculation as positive or negative, e.g. added or subtracted in the calculation.

title: Posting rule
body: Posting date

title: Posting rule
body: Choose from Transaction date or Settlement date. Decides whether the posting date of the created posting is set based on the transaction date or settlement date of the transaction the posting is created through.

title: Posting rule
body: Payment*

title: Posting rule
body: Choose from debit or credit. Determines whether the individual rule will be recorded to the debit or credit side.

title: Posting rule
body: A new individual rule is added to the posting rule or the changes made to the rule are saved with the + button, after which the rule is shown in the rule table below the posting rule basic information.

title: Posting rule
body: The individual rules within an entire posting rule are shown in the table, grouped under the rule-defining conditions of transaction type + security's chosen characteristic. If an individual rule is changed, it is then re-grouped if necessary - you can always see an up-to-date grouping of your individual posting rules.

title: Posting rule
body: The posting rule table allows you to see all the individual rules with a quick glance, and the information of the rules is divided into columns.

title: Posting rule
body: Name

title: Posting rule
body: The name represents the name of the posting rule group, e.g. the combination of transaction type and selected security characteristics that define when the individual rules within the group are applied. The group name is shown as "Transaction type name + Security character + Second security character", e.g. "Buy + Stock" or "Sell + Stock + Finland".

title: Posting rule
body: Account

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selected account of the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Posting date

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selection for the posting date for the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Credit/Debit

title: Posting rule
body: Shows the selection for the debit/credit for the individual rule

title: Posting rule
body: Charge type

title: Posting rule
body: Shows all the selected charge types as "Type 1 + Type 2 + Type 3". The list shows which charge types were checked for the individual rule and how, by adding or subtracting, they are calculated together.

title: Posting rule
body: To manage the posting rules more effectively, the following functions are available:

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an entire posting rule. To duplicate an entire posting rule set, e.g. all the individual rules defined within a posting rule set, click the Duplicate button on the left below the defined posting rule sets. A new posting rule set is created, and the code and name of the set are set with the text "-copy" at the end.

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating a group of rules. To duplicate a group of rules, e.g. all the individual rules with the same name / the same combination of transaction type and security characteristics, right-click the posting rule group and select "Duplicate". Define the combination of transaction type and security characteristic you want the copied rules to be applied to, and new rules are created with these new selections.

title: Posting rule
body: Duplicating an individual rule. To duplicate an individual rule, right-click the individual rule and select "Duplicate". The selections of the copied rule are shown as default - define the combination of transaction type and security characteristic you want the copied rule to be applied to, and a new rule is created with these new selections.

title: Posting rule
body: Exporting posting rules in the XLS file . To export rules as an Excel file, choose the rule set, click and download the file.

title: Posting rule
body: Exporting posting rules in the CSV file. To export the rules in the CSV file that you can edit and import back in the system, choose the rule set, click Export , and download the file.

title: Posting rule
body: Importing posting rules in the CSV file. To import a CSV file with posting rules, click Add posting rule, fill in the Name, unique Code , and Account set fields, and click Import to upload the file. Note that the CSV file must contain the same account as in the selected account set.

title: Available charge types
body: The following list describes charge types you can select in the first section of the posting rule definition. There are more available charge types categorised under tax types and transaction cost types.

title: Tax types
body: Tax types are listed in their own section under the first list of charge types. The available tax types consist of standard tax types in the system (see Tax types FA User guide) and custom tax types defined in Tax types. When you select multiple tax types, the system takes into account the sum of the values for the selected tax types.

title: Transaction cost types
body: Transaction cost types are listed in their own section under the tax types. The available transaction cost types consist of those defined in Preference - Transactions. When you select multiple transaction cost types, the system takes into account the sum of the values for the selected cost types.

title: Posting update
body: The Posting update section contains the following settings:

title: Posting update
body: Ask the user to confirm generation and updates of postings older than (excluding the date)

title: Posting update
body: A setting to prevent unintended changes in bookkeeping, for example, if the user edits an older transaction by mistake which can cause postings updates. If the postings that the user tries to update are older than the specified date, the system asks the user for confirmation.

title: Posting update
body: The system asks to confirm changes if the user modifies postings:

title: Posting update
body: Edits and saves a transaction in the Transaction window. The system asks the user to confirm the posting updates if they have configured posting generation when saving transactions in Preference (see General).

title: Posting update
body: Clicks Generate postings in the Transactions view.

title: Posting update
body: Creates a posting in the Transaction window or in the Bookkeeping view.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified posting currencies other than the portfolio currency. How are the values calculated?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Postings in the security currency use the transaction amounts where they are available. Wherever portfolio report items are used, the report FX is used to retrieve the security currency amount. Portfolio currency values are calculated using available report FX rates. For currencies specified other than the portfolio or security currency, available market FX rates are used to FX the security currency amounts to the corresponding posting currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified posting currencies other than portfolio currency. How is FX profit handled?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: FX profit considers the profit/loss between the security and the chosen currency as if it were the portfolio currency. This profit/loss is then converted with available rates to the system relative to the chosen currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified "Security types that get the purchase value from the cash purchase price of the account". What does this mean?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: For some security types, such as cash transactions, the definition of purchase price is not well defined. This setting allows you to set the purchase price for a cash-type transaction as the average purchase price of the cash in the account against which the transaction is booked. This price is the average FX rate on your cash transactions against your portfolio currency.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Example: The portfolio is in EUR. You have a USD account in which you deposited 100,000 USD at the rate of 1.25 EUR/USD. This leaves you with a purchase value of 80,000 EUR and an average purchase price of 0.8 EUR per USD. Any cash transactions that have a negative cash effect on this account are now assumed to have this as a purchased price. If you sell off the 100,000 USD on the account at a rate of 1.0 EUR/USD, the sold value in the portfolio currency is 100,000 EUR. From a portfolio perspective in EUR, this is a loss of 20,000 EUR.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: Any purchase price and profit realized on transactions with this set on the security type should also be visible in Analytics+. For example, any purchase value of future cashflows should be booked from the corresponding cashflow in/out transactions and viewable in Analytics+.

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: I have specified "Security types that get the purchase value from the cash purchase price of the account". Does this give me the true realized profit on FX spots/forwards?

title: Questions and answers about bookkeeping
body: No. The setting gives you the realized profit against the account's average purchase price of cash. A true realized profit on a FX spot or forward is compared against the spot price at settlement and what you contracted at inception. It is also compared against the spot pair in all cases, whereas the average price is compared against the account and portfolio (not necessarily the same as the spot/forward pair).

title: Related links
body: Standard bookkeeping rules in FA User guide.

title: Preference - Content and translations
body: Content and translations preferences include relevant preferences for flexibly defining the texts, translations and formatting used for different languages. These preferences allow you to override the default date formats, number formats and texts used to show dates, numbers and texts on FA's user interface.

title: Analytics+ columns
body: You can configure custom columns for Analytics+, for example, based on security key figures or mathematical formulas. To learn about adding columns to Analytics+, see Configuring Analytics columns in Preferences in FA User guide.

title: Date and decimal formats
body: Date and decimal formats allow you to define different date and decimal formats to be used for different user interface languages.

title: Date and decimal formats
body: For example, instead of showing dates always with the default format of "dd.MM.yyyy", you can set dates to be shown in formats such as "yyyy-MM-dd" or "MM/dd/yyyy". For numbers, you can control how many decimals are shown with number formatting. For example, use "#,##0" not to show any decimals, "#,##0.00" to always show two decimals, or "#,##0.######" to show up to six decimals if there are decimals to show.

title: Key figures
body: Key figures are available as selectable columns in different search views. For example, you can store credit ratings as a key figure for securities, view the latest credit ratings in the Securities view, and search for securities with a certain credit rating. You can also configure a key figure to be available to a specific portfolio or security type and only allow users to select values for the key figure from a pre-defined list of options.

title: Key figures
body: For instructions on adding key figures and configuring them as columns in Analytics+, see in Add a column based on a key figure FA Developer.

title: Key figures
body: When adding a new key figure, you need to specify the following information:

title: Key figures
body: Select where you want to use this key figure - Select if the key figure is associated with contacts, portfolios, or securities. The key figure is available in the corresponding window. You can only select one option.

title: Key figures
body: Define the types you want this key figure to be available for - You can restrict the key figure visibility to certain types only. For example, the key figure can be visible to "customers" but not other types of contacts. Enter the type codes as comma-separated list (for example: BOND,FUND). If you don't restrict the key figure visibility, it is available to all contacts, portfolios, or securities.

title: Key figures
body: Code - A unique code for the key figure. Use only alphanumeric values (letters a-z and numbers 0-9, no spaces or special characters). The key figure code is used to identify the key figure and you can't modify it after saving.

title: Key figures
body: Name - A name for the key figure, used throughout the FA Platform.

title: Key figures
body: Value type - Select what values users can record with this key figure. The default type for key figure values is numbers (integers). Other options are integer (whole number), string (text), double (number), and boolean (true/false options).

title: Key figures
body: Allow users to enter values manually or to select from a pre-defined list - Select if users need to enter values manually by typing them or if there should be a dropdown list of available options to enter (see Enter key figure values manually or select from a pre-defined list).

title: Key figures
body: Define the values users can select - If you selected the option "Select values from a predefined list" for the previous setting, you need to define the options that users can choose from. Define the options on separate rows. If you leave the list empty, users can't select a value for the key figure. See Enter key figure values manually or select from a pre-defined list.

title: Enter key figure values manually or select from a pre-defined list
body: You can control user input for key figure values with the Allow users to enter values manually or select from a pre-defined list setting. If values can be entered manually, users see a free input field for a number or text (depending on the key figure value type). If values are selected from a pre-defined list, users see a dropdown list of options. When defining the pre-defined values, you have two options:

title: Number formats
body: Number formats

title: Number formats
body: Number formats allow you to set the decimal separator used in the system according to a language locale which consists of a language and a country. You can view the languages and locales in the system in Preference - General.

title: Number formats
body: To define the number format for a language, enter the language locale in its column. For example, if you enter the language locale "fi_FI" in the "Suomi" column, the system uses a comma as the decimal separator when the language is Finnish. If you leave the language column empty, the system uses the default decimal separator.

title: Profile definitions
body: You can define and maintain custom fields for contacts, portfolios, and securities using the profile definition preferences. Profile definitions determine the content and fields in custom tabs and allow you to control where and to whom the tabs are shown. These preferences are available from FA 3.8 onward.

title: Available profile definitions
body: The profile definitions are categorized as follows:

title: Available profile definitions
body: Contact - Profile definitions linked to contacts, available as tabs in the Contact window.

title: Available profile definitions
body: Other

title: Available profile definitions
body: Profile definitions not classified as "Contact", "Portfolio", or "Security". These profiles are not shown as custom tabs in main windows but used to define the content of, for example, custom designs in FA Front or the Design-based importer extension.

title: Available profile definitions
body: Profile definitions added before FA 3.8 not yet classified as "Contact", "Portfolio", or "Security" (see Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities).

title: Available profile definitions
body: Portfolio - Profile definitions linked to portfolios, available as tabs in the Portfolio window.

title: Available profile definitions
body: Security - Profile definitions linked to securities, available as tabs in the Security window.

title: General settings
body: You can manage profiles with a single form. The syntax is technical but the main controls are available separately. The most important input is validated when you save the form.

title: General settings
body: Code - A unique identifier for the profile. You can use the code to sort custom tabs in the corresponding window. Custom tabs are sorted alphabetically (available from FA 3.8 onward).

title: General settings
body: Name - The name of the profile, used as the tab title in the corresponding window.

title: General settings
body: Where you want to use this profile - Where the profile is shown. Select "Contact", "Portfolio", "Security", or "Other". Select "Other" if you are using the profile for custom designs in FA Front or the Design-based importer extension.

title: General settings
body: Type - What technical syntax is used to define the profile content. You can choose "FA Back (XML UI)" which only allows you to define custom tabs in FA Back, or "FA Back and FA Front (Vaadin design)" which also allows you to define custom designs for FA Front.

title: General settings
body: Restrict this profile to be shown to roles - Controls the visibility of the profile in FA Back based on specific user roles. Define the roles as a semi-colon separated list. If left empty, all users can see the profile. For example, "ADMIN;BO" shows the profile only to users with the "ADMIN" or "BO" role.

title: General settings
body: Define criteria for when this profile is shown - Controls the visibility of the profile in FA Back based on the characteristics of contacts, portfolios, or securities. Define the characteristics as a comma-separated list that should be matched for the profile to be shown. If left empty, the profile is always shown. For example, "“group=FUND,type=INV;ASSET,language.code=EN” shows the profile to portfolios of type "INV" or "ASSET" with language "EN" in the group "FUND".

title: General settings
body: Editor / Preview / Generated XML - Content of the profile. In the Editor tab, you can enter the technical profile definition syntax. The Preview tab generates a user interface preview of the profile. The Generated XML tab shows you the XML generated automatically based on the profile.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: The profile definition Code determines if the profile is linked to a contact, portfolio, or security (if the profile classification is "Other", this logic is backward-compatible from FA 3.8 onward):

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: If the code begins with "CONTACT.", the profile definition is linked to contacts.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: If the code begins with "PORTFOLIO.", the profile definition is linked to portfolios.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: If the code begins with "SECURITY.", the profile definition is linked to securities.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: You can link profile definitions to specific contacts, portfolios, or security types by adding the type code after the profile definition code. For example, a profile definition starting with "CONTACT.1." is linked to contacts of the "Customer" type, and a profile definition starting with "PORTFOLIO.INV." is linked to investment portfolios of the "INV" type.

title: Linking a profile to contacts, portfolios, or securities
body: You can link contact profile definitions to specific contact subtypes by adding a semicolon and the subtype code to the profile definition code. For example, you can specify "CONTACT.1:FC" as the profile definition code. The profile is linked to contacts with the "Customer" type and fund companies (contact subtype) with the code "FC".

title: Defining the profile content
body: Use "Vaadin design" or "XML UI" syntax to define the profile content. For more information about defining profile content, see Profiles in FA Developer guide.

title: Texts
body: Texts allow you to override any texts visible in the user interface by defining them separately for different user interface languages. The overridden texts are applied both to FA Back and FA Front - whatever text you override, will be applied everywhere on the user interface.

title: Texts
body: Search for the default text or key, and override the text in the languages you want. For example, if you want to translate the texts within Analytics+, search with the code "analyticsPlus" and find the correct column with the name.

title: Texts
body: At the bottom, the Show only overridden texts / Show all texts button allows you to easily detect which formats or texts have been overridden.

title: Translations
body: Translations allow you to define translations to be used on the portfolio reports for the categorizations, classifications, and other configurations you have defined in Preference. The permanent translations of the reports, such as titles, headings, and columns, are translated and saved in the system. However, for example, security or transaction types used in the reports are set and defined in Preference and are not translated automatically: in order to be able to print fully translated reports, you need to define translations in Preference. In addition to reports, the translations are used when the language of the user interface is changed.

title: Translations
body: The preferences you can translate have been separated on different tabs. The information you can translate is divided into columns:

title: Translations
body: Code

title: Translations
body: The code of the preference you are translating, as defined in Preference.

title: Translations
body: Default

title: Translations
body: The default name of the preference you are translating, as defined in Preference. This is the text that will be used for your preference if you don't have any translations defined.

title: Translations
body: Languages

title: Translations
body: After the code and the default, the available languages are shown as a separate column, allowing you to define a different translation for each language. By default, the supported languages are English, Finnish, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian. Adding a corresponding language with the correct locale in the language preferences the allows you to define translations in that language.

title: Widgets
body: Widget preferences allow you to define widgets that you can select on your dashboard.

title: Preference - Taxation
body: In Preference → Taxation, you can configure preferences for tax types and default tax rates.

title: Default tax rates
body: Default tax rates are used to automatically fill in tax information when you run corporate actions or add transactions. In Taxation → Default tax rates, you can define default tax rates for different combinations of transaction type, security country or type, portfolio juridical form and tax country, and portfolio type and tags. A default tax rate only applies when all defined criteria are met.

title: Default tax rates
body: For example, you can define a default tax rate of 7,5% withholding tax for for all dividends on Finnish stocks which are recorded to portfolios owned by private persons in Finland.

title: Default tax rates
body: You can search existing default tax rates in the system using the search fields at the top of each column. You can also modify or delete an existing default tax rate by selecting it in the list.

title: Define a default tax rate
body: To add a new default tax rate, do the following:

title: Define a default tax rate
body: Click Add.

title: Define a default tax rate
body: Fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Default tax rate information.

title: Define a default tax rate
body: Click Save.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Default tax rates are defined with the following fields:

title: Default tax rate information
body: Transaction type*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Transaction type this default tax rate is used for (for example, buy, sell, or dividend).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security country*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security country this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Juridical form*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio juridical form this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tax country*

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio tax country this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security type

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security type this default tax rate is used for (if no security type is selected, the default tax type is used for all types of securities when other conditions are met).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security subtype

title: Default tax rate information
body: Security subtype this default tax rate is used for (if no security subtype is selected, the default tax type is used for all types of securities when other conditions are met).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tax rate

title: Default tax rate information
body: Default tax rate to use for the defined criteria combination.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tax type

title: Default tax rate information
body: Type of the default tax rate (tax types are defined in Preference - Tax types).

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio type

title: Default tax rate information
body: Type of portfolios this default tax rate applies to. If left empty, the default tax rate applies to all portfolio types.

title: Default tax rate information
body: Portfolio tags

title: Default tax rate information
body: Tags a portfolio has to have for this default tax rate to apply (optional). If multiple tags are entered, the portfolio has to match them all.

title: Tax types
body: Tax types are used to determine the type of tax recorded for a transaction, for example, capital gains tax or VAT. The Transaction window has two fields for taxes, and tax types configured in Preference view can help you identify and categorize these taxes. Tax types are also used to define default tax rates for running corporate actions.

title: Tax types
body: You can view and modify tax types in Taxation → Tax types.

title: Define a tax type
body: To add a new tax type, do the following:

title: Define a tax type
body: Click Add tax type.

title: Define a tax type
body: Fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Tax type information.

title: Define a tax type
body: Click Save.

title: Tax type information
body: Tax types are defined with the following fields:

title: Tax type information
body: Code*

title: Tax type information
body: The individual tax type code that separates it from other tax types.

title: Tax type information
body: Name*

title: Tax type information
body: The name of the tax type. The name of the tax type is shown in the Transaction window.

title: Tax type information
body: Profit

title: Tax type information
body: The selection tells whether the tax type has a profit effect. The profit effect indicates whether the amount of this type of tax will have an effect on the portfolio's profit and whether the amount of this type of tax will be included in the position's purchase value. By default, the profit effect is not selected, and the tax will not have an effect on the portfolio's profit or will not be included in the portfolio's purchase value.

title: Tax type information
body: Cash

title: Tax type information
body: The selection tells whether the tax type has a cash effect. The cash effect determines whether this type of tax has an effect on the portfolio's cash, i.e. is the amount of the tax deposited to or withdrawn from the portfolio's account with the transaction. By default, the cash effect is selected, and the tax has the same effect on the portfolio's account as the transaction does. If not selected, only the net price of the transaction without the tax of this type would affect the portfolio's cash.

title: Preference - Contacts
body: Contact preferences include relevant preferences for managing contacts. These preferences allow you to set the options available in the fields when defining the basic information of a contact or portfolio in the Basic info tab on the Contact or Portfolio window. The options you set up in these preferences allow you to flexibly group your portfolios.

title: Classification(s)
body: Classifications are used to categorize customers and other contacts. A classification consists of a code and a name. The code is used to identify the classification in the system and the name is used to view and choose the classification in the user interface.

title: Classification(s)
body: The basic classification ("Professional", "Non-Professional", "Not available") is pre-defined and mandatory for a contact. You can view the basic classifications in Preference → Contacts → Classification. You can modify the user interface name of a basic classification by selecting it, clicking Translate, and entering the modified name in the language column you want to use.

title: Classification(s)
body: You can also define custom classifications for contacts with the Classification 2-3 fields. For example, you can categorize your contacts based on MiFID regulations, and so on. Custom classifications are defined in Preference → Contacts → Classification 2-3.

title: Basic classifications
body: The following table shows the basic classification codes and names.

title: Contact types
body: In the Contact type preferences, you can define the contact subtypes available for contacts. Contact types and contact subtypes are used to categorize the contacts: For example, the contacts could be divided into customers, asset managers, custodians, and counters.

title: Contact types
body: For contacts, contact type is mandatory information. Available contact types are Customer (with the Fund Company and Asset Manager as subtypes), Advisor, Counterparty, Accountant, Issuer, Custody, and Lead.

title: Contact types
body: Contact types are fixed since certain FA Back functionality is linked to the contact type: only "Customers" can own portfolios and can be selected on the Overview, and "Counterparties", "Issuers" and "Custodies" are listed in the corresponding fields throughout the system. However, you can rename a contact type in Preference → Content and translations → Translations.

title: Contact subtypes
body: If you want to categorize your contacts even further, you can define contact subtypes in Preference. The definition of contact types has two levels: You can define contact subtypes under the pre-set contact types on the higher level. A contact subtype consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the contact subtype in the system, and the name is used to view and choose the contact subtype in the user interface.

title: Restricting access to contact types and contact subtypes
body: You can restrict the list of contact types available in the Contact type dropdown in the Contact window's Basic information and Contact view's extended search fields. For example, you can decide which user role(s) are allowed to use which contact types for the contacts they manage, especially useful in restricting the visibility of custom fields linked to a certain contact type.

title: Restricting access to contact types and contact subtypes
body: To restrict access to contact types, check the appropriate roles within the contact type or contact subtype preferences. Choose the user roles from the list of roles defined in the Admin console app (for details, see User details pane). If you don’t restrict a contact type to a specific user role, it will be visible to all users.

title: Identity
body: In Preference → Contacts → Identity, you can define the identities available for contacts. Identities are a mandatory field used to categorize the customers and other contacts. For example, the identity of a customer has to be known or verified due to MiFID regulations, and the identity selection can be used to determine whether the identity of the customer is known and how the customer was identified.

title: Identity
body: An identity consists of a code and a name. The code is used to identify the identity in the system and the name is used to view and choose the identity in the user interface. The following table shows the standard identities in the system.

title: Juridical form
body: In the Juridical form preferences, you can define the juridical forms available for contacts and portfolios. Juridical forms are used to categorize the customers and portfolios based on their legal stand. For example, the contacts and portfolios could be categorized into companies and private persons. For contacts and portfolios, a juridical form is mandatory.

title: Juridical form
body: In addition to grouping portfolios, the juridical forms chosen for a portfolio can be used for defining tax rates used in running corporate actions. The tax rates can be defined per portfolio's juridical form and tax country, thus a different tax rate can be defined for example for companies and private persons in Finland when running corporate actions. Also, the juridical forms are used for defining default tax rates used in running corporate actions.

title: Juridical form
body: The portfolios owned by a contact of the type Customer inherit the juridical form of the contact: by default, the juridical form of a portfolio is the same as the juridical form of the portfolio's primary contact's juridical form. Thus, when a new portfolio is created, the juridical form is by default set to be the same as the juridical form chosen for the customer.

title: Juridical form
body: Juridical forms can be defined in the Juridical form window in Preference. A juridical form consists of a code and a name: the code is used to identify the juridical form in the system, and the name is used to view and choose the juridical form in the user interface.

title: Contact window
body: The Contact window allows you to create a new contact or to view and edit the information of existing contacts. You can create a new contact through the menu in New - New contact, and you can view the information of existing contacts by double-clicking a contact either from your search result on the Contacts view or from the Overview.

title: Contact window
body: You can define the basic information of the contact in the first tab, and use the other tabs to define additional information for the contact. In the Basic info tab, the contact type determines the role of the contact in the system: a contact can be for example a customer, when portfolios can be added to the contact, or an asset manager. To switch between the tabs, click on them or use the icon at the bottom of the window.

title: Basic info
body: The Basic info tab allows you to define the basic information of the contact, such as ID and name. A red star indicates that a field is mandatory.

title: Basic info
body: The available fields are:

title: Basic info
body: Contact ID*. An individual ID defined for a contact – an internal customer ID or a sequential number from the CRM system. The contact ID separates a contact from other contacts (the system does not allow more than one contact with the same contact ID). The contact ID is used in search and import functions. Best practice is not to include special characters into the contact ID - only use numbers and letters (a-z). Contact ID can be shown in various listings, for naming reports and document directories. Do not enter the confidential information, such as the client's social security number, in this field.

title: Basic info
body: Contact name*. Name of the contact. Avoid the ">" character in the beginning of the contact's name - this will confuse the contact as a group when selected on the Overview.

title: Basic info
body: External ID. External ID for identifying a contact, for example, identity number or social security number. External IDs are used, for example, for authority reporting and for PEP and sanctions checks.

title: Basic info
body: Status*. Status of the contact: "Active", "Passive", or "Closed". The status allows you to categorize contacts. The recommended status to use for contacts you actively work with is "Active", because contacts with this status are shown everywhere in the system and can be worked with in the Overview. "Passive" and "Closed" contacts are not selectable in the Overview (to avoid cluttering the list of contacts you are actively maintaining), but you can still access contacts regardless of their status through the search views.

title: Basic info
body: Type*. Choose the contact type from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Contact types. The contact type affects the functions you can perform on a contact: for example, portfolios can be added only to contacts of the type Customer, and only contacts of the type Asset manager can be added as asset managers.

title: Basic info
body: Juridical form*. Choose the juridical form from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Juridical form. The juridical form of a contact affects the juridical form of a portfolio added to the contact: the default juridical form of a portfolio is the juridical form of the contact of the portfolio. However, the changing of the juridical form of the contact doesn't affect the juridical forms of the existing portfolios assigned to the contact. The juridical form affects the taxation of certain transactions added to the portfolios: when creating corporate actions, the tax associated with these is defined as a combination of juridical forms and tax countries of the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Classification* . Choose the classification from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Classification.

title: Basic info
body: Classification 2 and 3 . Choose the classification from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Classification.

title: Basic info
body: Issuer group. The issuer group – another issuer contact in the system that serves as a company group. Define the issuer group for the contact to view the Analytics+ figures by issuer group. The field is available only for contacts of the issuer type.

title: Basic info
body: Identity*. Choose the identity from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Identity.

title: Basic info
body: Tax country*. Choose the tax country from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Countries. The tax country of a contact affects the tax country of a portfolio added to the contact: the default tax country of a portfolio is the tax country of the contact of the portfolio. However, the changing of the tax country of the contact doesn't affect the tax countries of the existing portfolios assigned to the contact.

title: Basic info
body: Nationality. Choose the nationality from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Countries.

title: Basic info
body: Language. Choose the language to be used in portfolio reports from the alternatives, which are defined in Preferences - Language. The language of a contact affects the language of a portfolio added to the contact: the default language of a portfolio is the language of the contact of the portfolio. However, the changing of the language of the contact doesn't affect the languages of the existing portfolios assigned to the contact. The language chosen for a contact determines, which language is used in the portfolio reports when creating a report: the reports are created in the language of the portfolio. The translations for the security and transaction types to different languages are defined in Preferences - Internationalization. If no language is selected, the reports are printed out in Finnish and the abbreviations defined for security and transaction types are used.

title: Basic info
body: Transaction no. level. Choose from:

title: Basic info
body: Portfolio level - the system automatically generates a transaction number for a transaction, which is individual to each transaction within the portfolio.

title: Basic info
body: Contact level - the system automatically generates a transaction number for a transaction, which is individual to each transaction within all the portfolios of the contact.

title: Basic info
body: Date of birth. Contact's date of birth.

title: Basic info
body: Tags. Choose tags from the alternatives defined in Preferences - General - Tags. Tags can be defined in three different ways:

title: Basic info
body: Grouped tags (select one): you can select one tag from each tag group, grouped in separate drop downs. Only one tag in each tag group can be chosen. To group tags in a drop down, defined them with a hyphen as "group - tag", for example Reporting - 1m or Office - Helsinki.

title: Basic info
body: Grouped tags (select multiple): you can select multiple tags from each tag group, grouped as separate sets of check boxes. You can check multiple tags within each tag group. To group tags as a set of check boxes, defined them with a colon as "group : tag", for example Hobbies : Golf and Hobbies : Food&Wine.

title: Basic info
body: Individual tags: search for individual tags by typing the tag in the field and choosing the correct tag from the list below the field - all available tags are show from the downward arrow on the keyboard. You can select multiple individual tags.

title: Address info
body: In the Address info tab, you can add address information to a contact. You can simultaneously maintain multiple different addresses, for example "home address", "office address", "primary address" - whichever address information you need to maintain.

title: Address info
body: Add a new address with the Add address button, and define the address information in the available fields. A red star indicates a mandatory field.

title: Address info
body: Name* - the name of the address, the only mandatory field.

title: Address info
body: Address 1 - address.

title: Address info
body: Address 2 - address.

title: Address info
body: Zip code - postal code of the address

title: Address info
body: City - city of the address

title: Address info
body: Country - country of the address

title: Address info
body: Email - email address

title: Address info
body: Phone - phone number

title: Address info
body: Fax - fax number

title: Address info
body: Permission to use electronic communication - select, if electronic communication, such as email, can be used.

title: Address info
body: Permission to send marketing materials - select, if marketing material can be sent to the contact.

title: IDs
body: The IDs tab allows you to define external IDs for your contact. These IDs are used by other parties to identify the contact, and can be used for example to store LEI codes, CIF numbers or any other external Customer IDs.

title: IDs
body: Add a new ID with the Add ID button, and define the ID information in the available fields. A red star indicates a mandatory field.

title: IDs
body: External name* - the name of the ID (or who uses the ID, where is it from). When starting to type in an ID, the system automatically suggests ID names you have used previously.

title: IDs
body: External ID* - the external ID for the contact.

title: Representatives
body: The Representatives tab allows you to define representatives who can access the client’s portfolios and contact information. A representative is a user who manages and is responsible for the contact, or who otherwise represents the contact - for example, an advisor can represent their clients, or a private person can represent their company or children.

title: Representatives
body: To add a representative, click Add representative and choose the representative's contact from the drop-down menu. If you have representative tags set up in preferences (see Preference - Tags), you can use them to specify the representative's role for information purposes (for example, parent, company owner, and so on).

title: Representatives
body: To learn more about linking a representative to contact, see Set up limited visibility for one user and Set up limited visibility for many users.

title: Settlement place
body: The Settlement place tab allows you add settlement places defined in settlement place preferences as the contact's settlement place ( for more information, see Preference - Securities). Settlement places are for example defined to "Counter party" contacts when generating SWIFT messages from the system to settle trades - settlement place is then used to select the settlement place / exchange the counter party operates in and to define the account information of the counter party in the exchange.

title: Settlement place
body: Add a new settlement place with the Add settlement place button, and define the settlement place information in the available fields. The required information depends on the requirements from the settlement place and what you are using the settlement place information for.

title: Settlement place
body: Settlement place - select the settlement place you want to add, i.e. select the settlement place your want to settle trades with this counter party.

title: Settlement place
body: Name - shows the name of the selected settlement place.

title: Settlement place
body: Code - shows the code of the selected settlement place.

title: Settlement place
body: Define the account information of the contact within the selected settlement place:

title: Settlement place
body: Counter - define the counter information, usually as a BIC code.

title: Settlement place
body: Agent - define the agent information, usually as a BIC code.

title: Settlement place
body: Account - define the account information.

title: Key figures
body: The Key figures tab allows you to manually record values for different contact indicators. For example, you can store contact tax values or fee percentages that change over time.

title: Memo
body: Memo allows you to write optional information, notes or observations related to the contact. The contents of the memo are also shown in the Memo section on the Overview, when the contact is selected.

title: Memo
body: You can also import texts to the memo from a file through Import - Import contact memo, or to edit the contents of the memo directly from the Memo section on the Overview.

title: Documents
body: Documents allows you to manage documents related to your contact. For more information, see Document management.

title: Processes
body: The Processes tab allows you to run processes for your contacts, if contact-related processes have been defined for you in FA.

title: Saving a contact
body: Saving a contact saves the contact into the system, and after you save the contact, you can for example create portfolios to it. When editing the information of an existing contact, the system just updates the contact information - the updated information is picked up by the system automatically.

title: Saving a contact
body: At the bottom of the Contact window, you can:

title: Saving a contact
body: Save and close - saves the contact / the changes made to the contact information and closes the window.

title: Saving a contact
body: Save - saves the changes made to the contact information, and takes you back to the Basic info tab.

title: Saving a contact
body: Copy as new - copies all of the existing contact's information as a base for you to create a new contact with a new ID. This function copies all other contact information except for the Contact ID, since this information is contact-specific and related to only one single contact.

title: Related links
body: Manage contacts in FA User guide

title: Contract window
body: Contract window allows you to add, view, and modify contracts in the system. To create a new contract, open the Contract window from the New menu at the top or right-click a portfolio on the Overview. To view and modify existing contracts, click the Add Contract transaction in the Overview or in the Transactions view.

title: Contract window
body: Contract window is divided into Basic contract fields and Contract-specific fields.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Basic contract fields at the top above the grey divider allow you to enter information common to all types of contracts.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Portfolio*

title: Basic contract fields
body: The portfolio you want to enter the contract to.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Status*

title: Basic contract fields
body: Status of your contract, either Accepted (default), Not finished or Deleted. The status of your contract determines the status of the forward cashflow and cashflow transactions created based on the contract - all transactions are created with the same status as your contract. Only "accepted" transactions have an effect on your portfolio's positions and market value. Status allows you to record contracts to the system even when you have not accepted them yet, or delete the contract's effect from your portfolio without loosing the track of what kind of transactions were created based on it.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Reference

title: Basic contract fields
body: Reference of you contract. You can automatically generate the reference number with a question mark (?), when the system generates a reference with the formula portfolio ID * 100 000 + transaction external ID + control number. By default, the portfolio ID is used as a basis of the reference number, but if the portfolio ID is not a number, then portfolio external ID is used. If the portfolio external ID is not a number, then portfolio database ID is used. The control number is calculated based on the formula defined for forming reference numbers.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Counter, Counter portfolio

title: Basic contract fields
body: The counter and a counter portfolio for your contract. The first dropdown for the counter contact first lists contacts of the type Counter party and Custody in an alphabetical order, and then the rest of the contacts within the system in alphabetical order. The second dropdown for the counter portfolio lists all portfolios within the system in alphabetical order.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Market place

title: Basic contract fields
body: The marketplace (MIC) of the contract from the alternatives, which are defined in Marketplace preferences.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Settlement place

title: Basic contract fields
body: The settlement place (BIC) of the contract from the alternatives, which are defined in Settlement place preferences.

title: Basic contract fields
body: External ID

title: Basic contract fields
body: External ID / number of your contract. When creating a contract, the system automatically generates an external ID for it by determining the next available transaction number - the available number depends on whether you have selected transaction numbering to be handled on the portfolio or contact level within Transaction no. level field in the Contact window. For example, if the largest external ID in your portfolio at the moment is 123, the next transaction would get the external ID of 124. You can also modify the external ID manually or have the system re-generate it with the next available number by typing in a question mark (?). External ID can also include letters and other non-numeric characters - however, these can only be added manually and are not considered by the automatic external ID generation.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Description on statement

title: Basic contract fields
body: Contract description.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Internal info

title: Basic contract fields
body: Internal description of the contract visible only internally in the Contract window.

title: Basic contract fields
body: Tags

title: Basic contract fields
body: Choose tags from the alternatives defined in Tags Preferences under Transaction tags. You can define tags in three different ways:

title: Basic contract fields
body: Grouped tags (select one): you can select one tag from each tag group, grouped in separate dropdowns. Only one tag in each tag group can be chosen. To group tags in a dropdown, defined them with a hyphen as "group - tag".

title: Basic contract fields
body: Grouped tags (select multiple): you can select multiple tags from each tag group, grouped as separate sets of checkboxes. You can check multiple tags within each tag group. To group tags as a set of checkboxes, defined them with a colon as "group : tag".

title: Basic contract fields
body: Individual tags: search for individual tags by typing the tag in the field and choosing the correct tag from the list below the field - all available tags are shown from the downward arrow on the keyboard. You can select multiple individual tags.

title: Contract-specific fields
body: Contract-specific fields at the bottom below the grey divider allow you to enter your contract information.

title: FX Spots
body: The fields available are:

title: FX Spots
body: Contract date

title: FX Spots
body: The date when the contract takes place, i.e. the spot date. For FX Spot, the cashflow transactions occur on the contract date.

title: FX Spots
body: Spot section allows you to define the details of the spot cashflows. Information relevant to each cashflow is shown on the same row, with an FX rate in between the two rows.

title: FX Spots
body: Settlement date

title: FX Spots
body: The date when the contract cashflows settle. The settlement date is pre-filled after selecting the contract date.
