The settlement date is calculated by adding 2 business days to the contract date (settlement date = contract date + 2D), by default considering weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involved currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies (i.e. if EUR and USD are using a different holiday calendar, a day is considered a holiday if it is a holiday in either of the involve currencies' holiday calendar). You can also calculate the settlement date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the settlement date again with the above logic (especially useful if you change the involved currencies and want to make sure afterwards the settlement date is still correct with their linked holiday calendars).

title: FX Spots
body: Buy / Sell

title: FX Spots
body: The direction of the first cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell".

title: FX Spots
body: Currency

title: FX Spots
body: The currency of the first cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: FX Spots
body: Amount

title: FX Spots
body: Amount for buying / selling.

title: FX Spots
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: FX Spots
body: The spot FX rate, i.e. the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row. You can fetch the FX rate with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the latest available price for the contract date from the currency cross.

title: FX Spots
body: Sell / Buy

title: FX Spots
body: The direction of the first cashflow. Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above. If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: FX Spots
body: Currency

title: FX Spots
body: Define how much of the selected currency you are buying / selling. This amount is pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: FX Spots
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected on the spot date, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to.

title: FX Spots
body: Account (Currency)

title: FX Spots
body: The account to direct the cashflow in the selected currency. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency in the portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: FX Forwards
body: The fields available are:

title: FX Forwards
body: Contract date

title: FX Forwards
body: The date when the contract begins. For FX Forward, the forward cashflow positions appear in your portfolio on the contract date.

title: FX Forwards
body: Forward section allows you to define the details of the cashflows. Information relevant to each cashflow is shown on the same row, with an FX rate in between the two rows.

title: FX Forwards
body: Period

title: FX Forwards
body: The length of your forward contract. For example, you can select whether you are entering a 1 week or a 1 month contract. The period is used to calculate the settlement date of the forward cashflows.

title: FX Forwards
body: Settlement date

title: FX Forwards
body: Date when the contract cashflows settle, calculated by adding the selected period into a spot date calculated from the contract date (settlement date = contract date + 2D + period). The settlement date is pre-filled after selecting the contract date and period, but you can also calculate the settlement date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the settlement date again with the below logic. The settlement date is calculated based on the contract date and the period (when the period is something else than 2D) through:

title: FX Forwards
body: First calculating a spot date from the contract date (by adding 2 business days to the contract date, by default considering weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involves currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies), and

title: FX Forwards
body: Then adding the chosen period (e.g. 1W, 1M, etc.) to the calculated spot date.

title: FX Forwards
body: In case the resulting date is a holiday (based on weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involves currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies), then the next available business day is used as the settlement date.

title: FX Forwards
body: Example: The contract date is Thursday 2019-03-07 with 1W period. The system first calculates the spot date, which is two business days after 2019-03-07. There is a weekend in between, so the spot date is Monday 2019-03-11. To get the settlement date the system then adds 1 week to the spot date, resulting in Monday 2019-03-18.

title: FX Forwards
body: Transaction date

title: FX Forwards
body: Date when the cashflow transactions occur. This field behaves differently depending on contract preferences you set:

title: FX Forwards
body: With Create "Forward cashflow" securities based on the transaction date of the leg. The transaction date is pre-filled after setting the settlement date, and calculated by subtracting 2 business days from the settlement date (transaction date = settlement date - 2D). By default, the calculation considers weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involved currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies (i.e. if EUR and USD are using a different holiday calendar, a day is considered a holiday if it is a holiday in either of the involve currencies' holiday calendar). You can also calculate the transaction date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the transaction date again with the above logic (especially useful if you change the involved currencies and want to make sure afterwards the transaction date is still correct with their linked holiday calendars).

title: FX Forwards
body: With Create "Forward cashflow" securities based on the settlement date of the leg. The transaction date is filled after setting the settlement date, and the transaction date always equals to the settlement date. This ensures your forward cashflow positions stay open in your portfolio up until the settlement date (which is also the date the forward cashflow positions are discounted to). Transaction date is greyed out, and you cannot modify it. (Available from FA 3.10 onward - prior to this, the logic described first is used regardless of the selection in preferences)

title: FX Forwards
body: Buy / Sell

title: FX Forwards
body: The direction of the first cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell".

title: FX Forwards
body: Currency

title: FX Forwards
body: The currency of the first cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: FX Forwards
body: Amount

title: FX Forwards
body: Amount of the selected currency you are buying / selling.

title: FX Forwards
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: FX Forwards
body: Define the forward FX rate, i.e. the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row. You can fetch the FX rate with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the latest available price for the contract date from the currency cross.

title: FX Forwards
body: Sell / Buy

title: FX Forwards
body: The direction of the second cashflow. Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above. If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: FX Forwards
body: Currency

title: FX Forwards
body: The currency of the second cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: FX Forwards
body: Amount

title: FX Forwards
body: Amount of the selected currency you are buying / selling. This amount is pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined.

title: FX Forwards
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected on the forward date, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to.

title: FX Forwards
body: Account (Currency)

title: FX Forwards
body: The account to direct the cashflow in the selected currency. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency in the portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: FX Swaps
body: The fields available are:

title: FX Swaps
body: Contract date

title: FX Swaps
body: The date when the contract begins. For FX Swap, the near leg cashflows occur on the contract date (if the near leg is a spot), and the far leg the forward cashflow positions appear in your portfolio on the contract date.

title: FX Swaps
body: Near leg and Far leg sections allow you to define the details of the swap cashflows – near leg and far leg. The near leg of your swap can be either a spot or a forward, and the near leg fields are the same as the contract-specific fields for FX Forward with the following special fields:

title: FX Swaps
body: Near leg type - the type of the near leg as an FX Spot or an FX Forward.

title: FX Swaps
body: Near period - the length of the near leg of your swap. The near period is used to calculate the settlement date of the near leg cashflows.

title: FX Swaps
body: By default, the near leg is assumed to be a spot, and the near period is pre-filled to be 2D. When the near period is a spot, the settlement date is calculated as in contract-specific fields for FX Spots (settlement date = contract date + 2D), and transaction date is the same as the contract date.

title: FX Swaps
body: In case the near leg is a forward, you can change the length of the near leg to be something else, for example 1W or 1M. When the near leg is a forward, the settlement date and transaction date are calculated as in contract-specific fields for FX Forwards (settlement date = contract date + 2D + near period).

title: FX Swaps
body: Far leg section allows you to define the details for the end of the swap. The far leg of a swap is always a forward. The buy / sell selections should be opposite to the near leg. The currency selections should be the same as in your near leg, and the first cashflows amount the same as in your near leg. The far leg fields are similar to the contract-specific fields for FX Forward with the following special characters:

title: FX Swaps
body: Far leg type

title: FX Swaps
body: The type of the far leg, which is always FX Forward . Far period - select the length of the far leg of your swap. The far period is used to calculate the settlement date of the far leg cashflows by adding the selected period into the near leg settlement date (far leg settlement date = near leg settlement date + period). Otherwise, setting the settlement date and transaction date work as in contract-specific fields for FX Forwards.

title: FX Swaps
body: Buy / Sell

title: FX Swaps
body: The direction of the far leg cashflow, i.e. if you "buy" in your near leg, then you "sell" in your far leg. Currency - pre-filled to be the same as the currency you selected in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). The currencies have to be the same for the same cashflow for near leg and far leg - you are exchanging the currencies back and forth.

title: FX Swaps
body: Amount

title: FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be the same as the amount you defined in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). One of the amounts you are exchanging in the beginning has to be the same as you are exchanging at the end.

title: FX Swaps
body: Points

title: FX Swaps
body: Points that define how much the far leg FX rate changes compared to the near leg FX rate. A point is the smallest amount a price can move in a currency quote, and 1 point = 0.0001 change in far leg FX rate from the near leg FX rate. Points are used to calculate the far leg FX rate as near leg FX rate + points/10 000 = far leg FX rate. For example, 1.1464 + 10 points = 1.1464 + 0.001 = 1.1474

title: FX Swaps
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: FX Swaps
body: The far FX rate is the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. Pre-filled based on the points you entered. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row.

title: FX Swaps
body: Sell / Buy

title: FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above and opposite to the Buy / Sell selection you made in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection and the near leg buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: FX Swaps
body: Currency

title: FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be the same as the currency you selected in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). The currencies have to be the same for the same cashflow for near leg and far leg - you are exchanging the currencies back and forth. If you change this currency, the near leg currency is changed accordingly.

title: FX Swaps
body: Amount

title: FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: FX Swaps
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected for the dates defined on the near leg and the far leg, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to in the beginning and in the end of the contract.

title: FX Swaps
body: Account (Currency)

title: FX Swaps
body: Select the account you want to direct the cashflow in the selected currency to. The account selections always correspond to the cashflow you have defined on the same row on the left, and the caption of the account field indicates which currency cashflow you should select the account for. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency within your selected portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: Documents
body: Documents allows you to manage documents related to your contract (see Documents).

title: FX Spot
body: Contract type FX Spot is an agreement between two parties to buy one currency against selling another currency at an agreed price (FX rate) for settlement on a certain date. Entering an FX Spot automatically generates transactions for the two cashflows involved in your contract.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: For FX Spot, the contract-specific fields allow you to fill in information that is relevant for entering an FX Spot contract into the system.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: The fields available are:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Contract date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: The date when the contract takes place, i.e. the spot date. For FX Spot, the cashflow transactions occur on the contract date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Spot section allows you to define all relevant details of the spot itself. You can define your spot in terms of the two cashflows you would be getting on the spot date - information relevant to each cashflow is shown on the same row, with an FX rate in between the two rows.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Settlement date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: The date when the contract cashflows settle. The settlement date is pre-filled after selecting the contract date. The settlement date is calculated by adding 2 business days to the contract date (settlement date = contract date + 2D), by default considering weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involved currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies (i.e. if EUR and USD are using a different holiday calendar, a day is considered a holiday if it is a holiday in either of the involve currencies' holiday calendar). You can also calculate the settlement date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the settlement date again with the above logic (especially useful if you change the involved currencies and want to make sure afterwards the settlement date is still correct with their linked holiday calendars).

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Buy / Sell

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Allows you to select the direction of the first cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell".

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Select the currency of the first cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Define how much of the selected currency you are buying / selling.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Define the spot FX rate, i.e. the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row. The caption of the field indicates the currency cross you should fill in, and you can also fetch the FX rate with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the latest available price for the contract date from the currency cross.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Sell / Buy

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above. Determines the direction of the second cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell". If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Define how much of the selected currency you are buying / selling. This amount is pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected on the spot date, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Account (Currency)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Spots
body: Select the account you want to direct the cashflow in the selected currency to. The account selections always correspond to the cashflow you have defined on the same row on the left, and the caption of the Account field indicates which currency cashflow you should select the account for. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency within your selected portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: Security and cashflows for FX Spots
body: When saving an FX Spot, the system automatically creates a contract security and generates relevant cashflow transactions on the contract date.

title: FX Forward
body: Contract type FX Forward is an agreement between two parties to buy one currency against selling another currency at an agreed FX rate for settlement on a future date. Entering an FX Forward automatically generates forward cashflow positions until the end of your contract and relevant cashflow transactions for the end of your contract.

title: FX Forward
body: After FA 3.10, if you are creating a contract that ends in the future, the logic uses the latest FX rates available as the “settlement FX rate” of your contract - you might want to re-save your contract once your FX rates are up-to-date to update the settlement FX rates as well. Up-to-date "settlement FX rate" allows you to calculate profit/loss you made on your contract due to FX changes.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: For FX Forward, the contract-specific fields allow you to fill in information that is relevant for entering an FX Forward contract into the system.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: The fields available are:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Contract date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Date when the contract beings. For FX Forward, the forward cashflow positions appear in your portfolio on the contract date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Forward section allows you to define all relevant details of the forward itself. You can define your forward in terms of the two cashflows you would be getting in the future - information relevant to each cashflow is shown on the same row, with an FX rate in between the two rows.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Period

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Select the length of your forward contract. For example, you can select whether you are entering a 1 week or a 1 month contract. The period is used to calculate the settlement date of the forward cashflows.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Settlement date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Date when the contract cashflows settle, calculated by adding the selected period into a spot date calculated from the contract date (settlement date = contract date + 2D + period). The settlement date is pre-filled after selecting the contract date and period, but you can also calculate the settlement date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the settlement date again with the below logic. The settlement date is calculated based on the contract date and the period (when the period is something else than 2D) through:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: First calculating a spot date from the contract date (by adding 2 business days to the contract date, by default considering weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involves currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies), and

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Then adding the chosen period (e.g. 1W, 1M, etc.) to the calculated spot date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: In case the resulting date is a holiday (based on weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involves currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies), then the next available business day is used as the settlement date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Example: The contract date is Thursday 2019-03-07 with 1W period. The system first calculates the spot date, which is two business days after 2019-03-07. There is a weekend in between, so the spot date is Monday 2019-03-11. To get the settlement date the system then adds 1 week to the spot date, resulting in Monday 2019-03-18.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Transaction date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Date when the cashflow transactions occur. This field behaves differently (from FA 3.10 onward) depending on whether you have configured your contracts to create "Forward cashflow" securities based on the transaction date or settlement date of the leg in Preference - Contracts:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: With Create "Forward cashflow" securities based on the transaction date of the leg. The transaction date is pre-filled after setting the settlement date, and calculated by subtracting 2 business days from the settlement date (transaction date = settlement date - 2D). By default, the calculation considers weekends in Saturday/Sunday holiday calendar, or if the involved currency/currencies have already been filled in, the combined holiday calendars linked to the selected currencies (i.e. if EUR and USD are using a different holiday calendar, a day is considered a holiday if it is a holiday in either of the involve currencies' holiday calendar). You can also calculate the transaction date with a question mark (?), when the system calculates the transaction date again with the above logic (especially useful if you change the involved currencies and want to make sure afterwards the transaction date is still correct with their linked holiday calendars).

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: With Create "Forward cashflow" securities based on the settlement date of the leg. The transaction date is filled after setting the settlement date, and the transaction date always equals to the settlement date. This ensures your forward cashflow positions stay open in your portfolio up until the settlement date (which is also the date the forward cashflow positions are discounted to). Transaction date is greyed out, and you cannot modify it. (Available from FA 3.10 onward - prior to this, the logic described first is used regardless of the selection in preferences)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Buy / Sell

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Allows you to select the direction of the first cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell".

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Select the currency of the first cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Define how much of the selected currency you are buying / selling.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Define the forward FX rate, i.e. the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row. The caption of the field indicates the currency cross you should fill in, and you can also fetch the FX rate with a question mark (?), when the system fetches the latest available price for the contract date from the currency cross.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Sell / Buy

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above. Determines the direction of the second cashflow, i.e. whether the currency and amount you enter on the same row next to the field are "buy" or "sell". If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Select the currency of the second cashflow, i.e. the currency you are buying / selling.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Define how much of the selected currency you are buying / selling. This amount is pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected on the forward date, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Account (Currency)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Forwards
body: Select the account you want to direct the cashflow in the selected currency to. The account selections always correspond to the cashflow you have defined on the same row on the left, and the caption of the account field indicates which currency cashflow you should select the account for. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency within your selected portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: Security, forward cashflows and cashflows for FX Forwards
body: When saving an FX Forward, the system creates a contract security, produces forward cashflow positions into your portfolio between the contract date and the end of the contract, and generates relevant cashflow transaction for the end of the contract.

title: FX Swap
body: Contract type FX Swap is an agreement between two parties to exchange currency between two parties, in which they swap holdings in one currency for a holding in another currency for a fixed period of time.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: For FX Swap, the contract-specific fields allow you to fill in information that is relevant for entering an FX Swap contract into the system. You can fill in the information of the near leg and the far leg of your FX Swap in the same window - the fields allow you to manage both spot-forward swaps as well as forward-forward swaps.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: The fields available are:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Contract date

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Date when the contract beings. For FX Swap, the near leg cashflows occur on the contract date (if the near leg is a spot), and the far leg the forward cashflow positions appear in your portfolio on the contract date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near leg and Far leg sections allow you to define all relevant details of the swap. You can define your swap in terms of the two cashflows you would be exchanging once in the beginning (near leg) and then back in the end (far leg) - information relevant to each cashflow is shown on the same row.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near leg section allows you to define all relevant details for the beginning of the swap. The near leg of your swap can be either a spot or a forward, and the near leg fields are the same as the contract-specific fields for FX Forward with the following special characters:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near leg type - select the type of the near leg as an FX Spot or an FX Forward (available from FA 3.10 onward). For contracts created prior to FA 3.10, the system interprets your near leg's type based on its length: if the leg's settlement date is two days or less after the contract date (taking into account the involved currencies' holiday calendars), the near leg is an FX Spot, otherwise the near leg is an FX Forward.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Near period - select the length of the near leg of your swap. The near period is used to calculate the settlement date of the near leg cashflows.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: By default, the near leg is assumed to be a spot, and the near period is pre-filled to be 2D. When the near period is a spot, the settlement date is calculated as in contract-specific fields for FX Spots (settlement date = contract date + 2D), and transaction date is the same as the contract date.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: In case the near leg is a forward, you can change the length of the near leg to be something else, for example 1W or 1M. When the near leg is a forward, the settlement date and transaction date are calculated as in contract-specific fields for FX Forwards (settlement date = contract date + 2D + near period).

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Far leg section allows you to define all relevant details for the end of the swap. The far leg of your swap is always a forward, and the buy / sell selections should be opposite to your near leg, the currency selections the same as in your near leg, and the first cashflows amount the same as in your near leg. When you change these values in either of the legs, the other leg is changed accordingly. The far leg fields are similar to the contract-specific fields for FX Forward with the following special characters:

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Far leg type

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Shows the type of the far leg, which is always FX Forward (available from FA 3.10 onward). Far period - select the length of the far leg of your swap. The far period is used to calculate the settlement date of the far leg cashflows by adding the selected period into the near leg settlement date (far leg settlement date = near leg settlement date + period). Otherwise, setting the settlement date and transaction date work as in contract-specific fields for FX Forwards.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Buy / Sell

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). Determines the direction of the far leg cashflow, i.e. if you "buy" in your near leg, then you "sell" in your far leg. If you change this selection, the near leg buy / sell selection is changed accordingly. Currency - pre-filled to be the same as the currency you selected in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). The currencies have to be the same for the same cashflow for near leg and far leg - you are exchanging the currencies back and forth. If you change this currency, the near leg currency is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be the same as the amount you defined in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). One of the amounts you are exchanging in the beginning has to be the same as you are exchanging at the end. If you change this amount, the near leg amount for the same cashflow is updated accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Points

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Allows you to define how much the far leg FX rate changes compared to the near leg FX rate. A point is the smallest amount a price can move in a currency quote, and 1 point = 0.0001 change in far leg FX rate from the near leg FX rate. Points are used to calculate the far leg FX rate as near leg FX rate + points/10 000 = far leg FX rate. For example, 1.1464 + 10 points = 1.1464 + 0.001 = 1.1474

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: FX rate (currency cross)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled based on the points you entered. The far FX rate is the price you agreed to do the exchange between the two currencies you selected. The FX rate is used to convert the amount you have entered on the upper row to the amount on the lower row, and the caption of the field indicates the currency cross you should fill in.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Sell / Buy

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be opposite to the buy / sell selection you made above and opposite to the Buy / Sell selection you made in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). If you change this selection, the above buy / sell selection and the near leg buy / sell selection is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Currency

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled to be the same as the currency you selected in the near leg for the same cashflow (on the same row). The currencies have to be the same for the same cashflow for near leg and far leg - you are exchanging the currencies back and forth. If you change this currency, the near leg currency is changed accordingly.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Amount

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Pre-filled based on the amount you entered on the upper row and the FX rate you defined. If you update this amount, the system automatically calculates the FX rate to ensure all calculations match.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Accounts section allows you to define the accounts affected for the dates defined on the near leg and the far leg, i.e. which accounts the buy and sell cashflows are directed to in the beginning and in the end of the contract.

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Account (Currency)

title: Contract-specific fields for FX Swaps
body: Select the account you want to direct the cashflow in the selected currency to. The account selections always correspond to the cashflow you have defined on the same row on the left, and the caption of the account field indicates which currency cashflow you should select the account for. The dropdown lists accounts in the selected currency within your selected portfolio, and the account filed is pre-filled if your selected portfolio only has one account in the selected currency.

title: Security, forward cashflows and cashflows for FX Swaps
body: When saving an FX Swap, the system creates a contract security, generates relevant cashflows in the beginning of the contract, produces forward cashflow positions into your portfolio between the contract date and the end of the contract, and generates relevant cashflow transaction for the end of the contract.

title: Yield curves view
body: The Yield curves view allows you to view the observations of a yield curve defined in the Yield curve Preferences.

title: Yield curves view
body: Yield curve is a curve showing several interest rates across different times - yield is actually only known with certainty for a few specific maturity dates, while the other maturities are calculated by interpolation. The Yield curves view allows you to identify these points the yield is know for on a specific date. Select a yield curve you want to view, and you can see the values for different dates for the different tenors (i.e. different maturities) associated with your curve. The values are picked up from the market data entires of the securities associated with the selected yield curve with different tenors.

title: Yield curves view
body: You can also export the results as an XLS file.

title: Analytics+
body: Analytics+ allows you to easily analyze your portfolios, providing you with an extensive set of analytical key figures to analyze your investments.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Setting up analysis

title: Setting up analysis
body: Choose if you need to analyze portfolios (Groups, contacts, portfolios tab) or securities (Securities tab).

title: Setting up analysis
body: For portfolios, analysis parameters are:

title: Setting up analysis
body: Group, customer or portfolio you want to analyze.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Grouping for your analysis. You can group your analysis with:

title: Setting up analysis
body: Portfolios.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Security-related parameters, such as asset classes and types, security type, classifications, countries, marketplace, currencies, issuer or issuer group.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Pre-defined combinations, such as Asset type and portfolio, Security type and subtype, Portfolio and sub portfolio, or Portfolio and asset type.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Custom grouping, when you can freely select the grouping levels from the available alternatives. If you want to include the actual position level in your analysis, select "Security", "Position" or "Positions by customer" as the last grouping option.

title: Setting up analysis
body: When grouping with asset type selection, you are also required to select which allocation group is used in grouping your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Date range for your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: For securities, analysis parameters are:

title: Setting up analysis
body: Security you want to analyze (you can select multiple securities).

title: Setting up analysis
body: Date range for your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Benchmark index chosen from the general benchmarks defined in Preferences. To learn more, see Preference - Portfolios.

title: Setting up analysis
body: When you choose the parameters, the Analyze button turns black to indicate you changed your criteria and should update your analysis.

title: Setting up analysis
body: Analytics+ also allows you to save your frequently used analysis and different sets of selected columns for later use.

title: Results of the analysis
body: Based on your selected parameters, the analysis is presented as a table with analytical key figures accompanied with a return graph and allocation pie chart. Remember that your analysis (or the analytical key figures) can be exported as an Excel or PDF file, and the graphs at the bottom can be printed out or downloaded as a PDF or image files.

title: Table with analytical key figures
body: The table at the top allows you to select your desired columns from a wide range of different analytical figures. All the analytical figures are available for the selected time period and fixed time periods of 1, 3, 6, 9, 12 months and year-to-date (YTD). See below for a comprehensive list of available analytical figures.

title: Table with analytical key figures
body: You can also hide positions through right-clicking the table, allowing you to easily and effectively view the analysis only on the group level. Whether the positions are hidden or shown is remembered for your user name.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: The graphs at the bottom visualize the overall performance for the selected time period, show the purchase value compare to market value, allowing you to track how your portfolios’ value has developed, and draws the current date's allocation for the selected portfolio(s).

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: You can easily re-draw the performance and allocation graphs for different visualizations:

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Select one of the pre-define time intervals to zoom in to the chart, or drag an area of the chart with your mouse you want to zoom in to.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Select an individual position or group (i.e. an individual row) from the table to re-draw the return graph for the selected position or group.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Select multiple positions or groups to re-draw the return graph for comparison.

title: Return graph and allocation pie chart
body: Click a point in the return graph to re-draw the allocation pie to show the selected day's allocation.

title: Export time series of data
body: Analytics+ provides you with tools to export time series of underlying data from Analytics+. This provides you with means to figure out how different figures are calculated in Analytics+ and how the underlying data has changed over time. You can also use the exported time series to further enrich your data, for example to apply further calculations in a spreadsheet or turn the time series into diagrams. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Export time series of data
body: Right-click your selection in Analytics+ and choose to Export time series of all underlying data as XLSX or Export time series of TWR-related data as XLSX. Exports contain:

title: Export time series of data
body: Time series of the selected data based on your selected date range, each day’s values on its own row.

title: Export time series of data
body: All underlying data available in Analytics+ or TWR-related data with relevant formulas for you to track how TWR was calculated each day.

title: Export time series of data
body: Each time series on its on sheet in the Excel, if you multi-selected rows before taking the export.

title: Export time series of data
body: The time series export does not export the columns you have selected in Analytics+ nor the values shown in Analytics+ columns - the time series export exports the time series of the underlying "raw" data that Analytics+ uses to calculate the figures it shows, such as TWR % for a specific time period.

title: Export time series of data
body: You can flexibly export different data sets through selecting different levels in your analysis. You can export data for individual positions, for any available group level (e.g. “Stocks” or “Funds”), or for total “Investments”. Select different portfolios or groups to aggregate data, different groupings to gain new levels to export data from, and different time periods to control the length of your time series.

title: Figures available in Analytics
body: The tables below list the main measurements and formulas available in Analytics+. In addition to the below described measures, different time periods (1, 3, 6, 12 months and year-to-date (YTD)) are available for certain key ratios. In addition, you can select Code and Name.

title: Figures available in Analytics
body: Logarithmic (natural) returns are used as a input in most of the calculations.

title: Figures available in Analytics
body: New columns are added into Analytics+ in each version - if you are running an older version of FA, you might not have all the below columns available. Refer to the Release notes for when new values are introduced.

title: Risk-adjusted performance measures
body: Risk-adjusted measures listed below makes it easier to compare different assets, portfolios and securities. Different to basic performance measures, these measures take also into consideration the riskiness of the investment.

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Certain key ratios are available also for benchmark (identified with "Bm" at the end of the column name).

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: There is a specific logic to determine which benchmark is used in which scenario:

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Portfolio's benchmark (if it exists) is always used on the portfolio level, when:

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: investments are grouped by portfolio

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: the analysis is taken on a single portfolio

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: If portfolio has a benchmark that a) is composed of one or many instruments (usually indices) and b) instrument is linked to a sector that is used in the grouping of the analysis => that instrument is used as a benchmark for the sector

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Otherwise, if the sector has a default benchmark defined in Preferences - Asset classes and types => that benchmark is used as a benchmark for the sector

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Benchmark aggregation is also supported up or down the grouping selected for the analysis with the following conditions:

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Benchmarks are aggregated up if the parent does not have its own benchmark (e.g. sector benchmarks are summed up with weighted daily average of TWR Bm to the parent group and sub-portfolio benchmarks are summed up to the main portfolio if sub-portfolios are included in the grouping). If the parent portfolio has content, it will be considered one of the child portfolios in analytics+ when using "Portfolio and subportfolio" grouping. Therefore, the aggregation logic works only if the parent portfolio is empty.

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Aggregated values never replace actual values (e.g. sector benchmarks or sub-portfolio benchmarks are not aggregated to portfolio, if the portfolio has its own benchmark).

title: Measures of benchmarks
body: Benchmarks are aggregated down as well (e.g. sector benchmark is used in instruments under the sector benchmarks). However, this does not apply to the portfolio benchmark. only to sector benchmarks.

title: Add a column based on a key figure
body: You can add custom columns based on key figures into the different search views and Analytics+. To learn how to do this, follow the instructions below.

title: Add a column based on a key figure
body: If the key figure you want to add as an Analytics+ column isn't already in the system, configure it in Preference first. To learn how to add key figures, see Add key figures in FA User guide.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: You can add key figure values for contacts, portfolios, or securities by entering them manually in the respective windows or by importing them.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: To add key figure values manually in FA Back, do the following:

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Open the Key figures tab in the Contact, Portfolio, or Security window.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: On the left side of the tab, select the key figure and click Add new value.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Define the date and value.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: Click Add.

title: Step 1 - Fill in key figure values
body: For more information about importing key figures, see File formats for importing securities and security prices and File formats for importing contacts and portfolios in FA Back reference.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: To configure a key figure as an Analytics+ column, do the following:

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Open Preference → Content and translations → Analytics+ columns.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Click Add new column and fill in the fields:

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select how you want to define the column - Select "Based on a security key figure".

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Code* - A unique code for the column. You can't change the code after saving.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Name* - Name for the column.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Description - Optional description of the column content, shown when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Link - Optional link for more information about the column, shown when selecting columns in Analytics+.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select the security key figure you want to use as a column - Choose the key figure to link to the column from the dropdown list.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Select how to calculate values on group levels -

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Do you want to override the default formatting? Choose if you want to specify a custom formatting for the column. If you select "Yes, override formatting", you also need to specify the format.

title: Step 2 - Set up the Analytics+ column
body: Click Save.

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered
body: This rule removes the "LEI code missing" portfolio tag and unlocks the contact's portfolios if the contact has LEI code entered in the Contact window, MiFiR tab.

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered

title: Unlock contact's portfolios when LEI is entered

title: API integrations
body: GraphiQL is a query tool available in FA Developer App. The tool can be used to define queries and mutations. It features a GraphQL editor, as well as documentation for the available GraphQL endpoints.

title: API integrations
body: GraphQL API provides many customization opportunities, for example:

title: API integrations
body: Building an integration between FA and an external application. A good example of this would be an integration between FA and your version of FA Client Portal.

title: API integrations
body: Building a custom JSReport (for details about custom reports, see the Reporting section). JSReports use GraphQL API to fetch the report data from FA Back.

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app
body: The GraphQL API view provides you access to the GraphiQL client to run queries and mutations to the FA GraphQL API.

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app

title: GraphQL API view in FA Developer app

title: Import and modify data via mutation API
body: Import and modify data via mutation API

title: Overview
body: You can import or modify FA data via GraphQL mutation API. When you import an object (for example, a contact or a portfolio), you need to provide all required fields as a parameter. When modifying an object you need to give minimum information that is enough to identify the entity. Imported attributes are updated, the left out attributes keep their previous values.

title: Overview
body: To import or modify different object types, use the following endpoints:

title: Overview
body: Contacts => importContacts

title: Overview
body: Portfolios => importPortfolios

title: Overview
body: Securities => importSecurities

title: Overview
body: Transactions => importTransactions

title: Overview
body: Trade orders => importTradeOrders

title: Overview
body: Security prices => importPrices

title: Overview
body: You can adjust the import behavior by using importGeneral endpoint and specifying the import parameters as you need. The import parameters are listed below:

title: Overview
body: importGeneral:

title: Overview
body: rows : list of objects to import (mandatory)

title: Overview
body: withRules : boolean whether to run rules when importing (default = false)

title: Overview
body: importAsync : boolean whether to use asynchronous importing or not (default = false)

title: Overview
body: mode / sMode / pMode / prMode / trMode / oMode / cMode : option to control import behavior for all object types (mode) or specific object type (sMode / pMode / prMode / trMode / oMode / cMode). Available options are:

title: Overview
body: 0 - insert and update (default)

title: Overview
body: 1- insert only

title: Overview
body: 2 - update only

title: Overview
body: Each endpoint can be used to import or update one or many objects in one request. The response identifies if the request was successful or if it had errors (specified in the response).

title: Define the request
body: For a valid request such as below, you need to:

title: Define the request
body: Define the mutation endpoint to use.

title: Define the request
body: Define all required fields as attributes, as described in FA importing formats. In the request below, for example, the required fields for importing contacts are "Contact ID", "Name", "Type", "Juridical form", "Status", "Tax country", "Classification", and "Identity" (see FA Format for importing contacts in FA Back reference).

title: Define the request
body: You need to define the request content as a list in the parameter with the syntax from FA importing (see Importing in FA Back reference). However, you need to define the attributes without the prefix used in FA importing. For example, in FA importing, contact name is defined as "c.name", so in the mutation API, you need to define this attribute as "name".

title: Define the request
Define the request
body: You can find an example of how to use importGeneral to control whether to run rules in Import data and trigger a business rule.

title: Interpret the response
body: The response structure is similar to the request. The result contains a list of map structures. Each item in the list presents an object that was imported. All attributes including the ones not explicitly used in the request are returned. The attributes are prefixed. For example, contact name is c.name. The success is indicated in the importStatus attribute with the OK value.

body: If required attributes are missing or the code is incorrect, the importStatus attribute has the ERROR value. Each attribute with an error is marked with ERROR (ERROR:[ImportError.required] in case the required value is missing).

title: Handle position and account interest
body: You can use the FA system to calculate, track, and capitalize account interest for fund portfolio positions and cash accounts. The system calculates accrued interest every time you calculate NAV or fees if you set up a separate fee workflow (see Ongoing fees).

title: Handle position and account interest
body: The following sections describe how you can handle account interest for fund portfolio holdings and fund cash accounts, including how to capitalize accrued account interest.

title: Calculate accrued interest on fund portfolio positions
body: Accrued interest on the fund portfolio holdings is calculated automatically based on the fixings information entered for securities in FA Back. To learn more, see Bonds in FA User guide.

title: Calculate accrued interest on fund portfolio positions
body: You can track the accrual for fund portfolio holdings in the NAV overview in the "Accrued interest" row (see View and check NAV calculation).

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: The system uses the following formula to calculate accrued account interest:

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Accrued interest

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Account balance

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Base interest rate

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: spread

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: Number of days in a year

title: Calculate and capitalize accrued account interest
body: In this formula, account balance is the balance at the beginning of the day, base interest rate is determined by an index or a fixed or floating rate, and spread is interest on top of the base rate that you can specify depending on the account balance.

title: Set up account interest
body: To set up account interest for a fund, you need to specify the account interest details by doing the following:

title: Set up account interest
body: In the NAV status view, click on the fund to open the side pane and then open the Fund wizard by clicking the icon.

title: Set up account interest
body: In the Basic info tab, select a cash account, click on Interest details, and fill in the fields. For field descriptions, see Basic info tab.

title: Set up account interest
body: Click Save.

title: Set up account interest
body: The system now starts accruing interest on the account. You can track the accrual in the NAV overview in the "Accrued account interest" row (see View and check NAV calculation).

title: Capitalize accrued interest in FA Back
body: To capitalize the interest accrued by fund investments, follow the instructions in steps 2 and 3 in Set up and run account interest (FA User guide). You can skip step 1 because fund account interest is already set up.

title: Capitalize accrued interest in FA Back
body: The system creates the capitalization transaction when you execute the account interest run. You can also schedule the run for later.

title: Use four-eyes approval of NAV
body: You can set up four-eyes approval to ensure that NAV is calculated and accepted by two separate users. When four-eyes approval of NAV is enabled, you can't accept NAV yourself after calculating it; you have to wait for another user to handle the acceptance.

title: Use four-eyes approval of NAV
body: To enable four-eyes approval of NAV, do the following:

title: Use four-eyes approval of NAV
body: Open NAV status view, click the icon, and select Settings.

title: Use four-eyes approval of NAV
body: Tick the checkbox Use four-eyes approval of NAV.

title: Use four-eyes approval of NAV
body: Click Save.

title: Use four-eyes approval of NAV
body: Four-eyes approval is now enabled for all funds. You can disable four-eyes approval by unticking the same setting. Both users can add comments regarding the calculation and acceptance in NAV overview, Details tab (see View NAV details and comments).

title: Calculate NAV
body: You can calculate NAV for one or more funds in the NAV status view. You can also enable four-eyes approval of NAV to ensure that two separate users calculate and accept the NAV (see Use four-eyes approval of NAV).

title: Calculate NAV
body: To calculate NAV for one fund, do the following:

title: Calculate NAV
body: Click on a fund in the NAV status view. Make sure the fund status is "Pending NAV" or "Pending unofficial NAV".

title: Calculate NAV
body: Click Calculate NAV in the Fund details pane.

title: Calculate NAV
body: Check the calculation details and warnings (see View and check NAV calculation). You can add comments to the NAV calculation in NAV overview, Details tab.

title: Calculate NAV
body: If you need to fix the calculation, you can recalculate NAV or delete the recent calculation (see the sections below). If the calculation is correct, NAV can be accepted (see Accept NAV).

title: Calculate NAV
body: The fund status changes accordingly. You can also calculate NAV for multiple funds simultaneously by selecting the funds in the NAV status view and clicking Calculate NAV.

title: Recalculate NAV
body: If you need to correct the underlying data related, for example, to fee or trade orders after you calculated NAV:

title: Recalculate NAV
body: Make the necessary fixes.

title: Recalculate NAV
body: Select the fund in the NAV status view and click Recalculate NAV.

title: Recalculate NAV
body: You can view the calculation result in the NAV overview. For details, see View and check NAV calculation.

title: Delete NAV calculation
body: You can delete an NAV calculation, for example, if there is an error in the calculation schedule. To delete an NAV calculation, do the following:

title: Delete NAV calculation
body: In the NAV status view, double-click on the fund to open the NAV overview.

title: Delete NAV calculation
body: Click Delete calculation.

title: Delete NAV calculation
body: The NAV calculation data is deleted, and you can calculate NAV again.

title: Stop NAV calculation in progress
body: You can interrupt an ongoing NAV calculation.

title: Stop NAV calculation in progress
body: We don't recommend stopping an ongoing NAV calculation unless you are confident in what you are doing.

title: Stop NAV calculation in progress
body: To stop the NAV calculation, do the following:

title: Stop NAV calculation in progress
body: Click on the fund in the NAV status view to open the Fund details pane.

title: Stop NAV calculation in progress
body: Click Stop calculation.

title: Stop NAV calculation in progress
body: The NAV calculation is cancelled, and the fund returns to the "Pending NAV" status.

title: Roll back failed calculation
body: You can roll back a failed NAV calculation caused by a system error. Such a situation is indicated by the fund status being "Error". To roll back a failed NAV calculation, do the following:

title: Roll back failed calculation
body: Click on the fund in the NAV status view to open the Fund details pane.

title: Roll back failed calculation
body: Click Roll back failed calculation.

title: Roll back failed calculation
body: The fund returns to the "Pending NAV" status.

title: View and check NAV calculation
body: Double-click the fund in the NAV status view to open NAV overview. This view contains more detailed information about the NAV in different tabs:

title: View and check NAV calculation
body: NAV summary tab shows a summary of NAV for the entire fund.

title: View and check NAV calculation
body: Share classes tab shows NAV per fund share class.

title: View and check NAV calculation
body: Warnings tab shows warnings related to the NAV calculation, fund portfolio and share classes, and limits.

title: View and check NAV calculation
body: Details tab shows the time of latest NAV calculation and acceptance and comments relating to them.

title: View NAV summary and NAV per share class
body: Double-click the fund in the NAV status view to open NAV overview. In the NAV summary tab, you can see an NAV summary for the entire fund. In the Share classes tab, you can see NAV per fund share class. The following sections describe these tabs in more detail.

title: NAV summary
body: The NAV summary tab shows you the net asset value of the entire fund calculated as the fund’s gross asset value (GAV) subtracted by the fund’s fees:
